keyTakeAways: A bear attack in Japan has led to serious injuries for runner Billy Halloran, who sustained a broken arm and leg injuries during a routine run in the Myoko woods.
Bear attacks have increased significantly in Japan, with over 100 people injured and seven killed in 2025, the highest number since 2006.
Climate change is disrupting bear food sources, causing bears to move into urban and suburban areas in search of food, increasing human-bear conflicts.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the surge in attacks.
Local residents use preventive measures such as carrying bells, loud music, or bear spray to reduce the risk of encounters.
Billy Halloran’s experience highlights the danger of outdoor activity in bear-prone areas and the psychological trauma that can follow such attacks.
Despite injuries, Halloran remains committed to returning to running and nature, supported by the local running community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a New Zealander runner from Auckland, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the Myoko woods in Japan. The attack, part of a growing trend of bear incidents in Japan—driven by climate change altering bear food availability—resulted in serious injuries, including a bitten-off arm and leg wounds. Halloran survived after escaping and calling for help, and he has undergone multiple surgeries. The Japanese government has responded with increased measures to manage bear populations. The incident underscores the rising danger of human-wildlife conflict in urbanizing, climate-affected regions and highlights both personal and societal responses to ecological shifts.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
